communications.subject: Fwd: RE: Maryland Public Information Act Request: Request for Your Agency's 2022 Roster & Salary Data (Landover Hills Police Department)
communications.communication:
Hello,
 
Attached is the information as you requested, per your link.  
 
Thank you, Chief Liberati
 
 
 
 
To Whom It May Concern:
 
Pursuant to the Maryland Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records for every sworn officer and civilian member of the Landover Hills Police Department for fiscal year 2022:
1. First and last name;
2. Unique sequence number;
3. Race;
4. Gender;
5. Hire date;
6. 2022 salary;
7. 2022 overtime
 
The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.
 
In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. Alternatively, please consider waiving any fees, pursuant to § 4-206(e)(2)(ii) of the General Provisions Article, as this request is on behalf of individuals served by the Maryland Office of the Public Defender, a state government agency, which solely serves indigent citizens of Maryland. As a result, my request for the above-listed public records is in the public interest. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.
 
Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.
 
Sincerely,
 
Deborah Levi
Director of Special Litigation
Maryland Office of the Public Defender
(443) 272-1068
 

Robert V. Liberati, Jr. #3150
Chief of Police
Landover Hills, Maryland
6904 Taylor Street
Landover Hills, MD 20784
R.liberati@landoverhills.us
O (301) 773-6400
Fax (301) 341-9886

Retired Major PGPD #1345, President PCAPGC 2021 & 2022

FBINA #258

title: Vendor Invoice/Purchase Order Spreadsheet - Whittier CA Police

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Vendor Invoice/Purchase Order Spreadsheet - Whittier CA Police
communications.communication:
Hello:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any spreadsheet or list maintained by the WPD showing all invoices and purchase orders submitted by or paid to vendors.  If such a spreadsheet can be produced from the Department’s accounting software showing amount of payment, date of payment, payee, and description of reason for payment, then I am requesting that spreadsheet.   Please cover a period going back to 2012.  

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

*The requested documents will be made available to the general public via Muckrock, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. I am a published citizen-journalist with articles in the Long Beach Beachcomber and on FORTHE.org. My research has been featured by the Los Angeles Times, Long Beach Post, Knock-LA, and other local publications.

Sincerely,

Gregory Buhl
lead researcher at CheckLBPD.org

communications.subject: Public Records Request - City of Whittier
communications.communication:
Good morning Gregory Buhl,

We are in receipt of 19 Public Records Request to the City of Whittier. The City is currently determining if there are any records pertaining to your request. Once completed, City staff will notify you of any findings, and possible fees associated with reproducing documents. In the event we require additional information on the scope of your request, we will reach out for clarification before we proceed to ensure we properly assist with your request. If a modification to the original request is made or if a clarification is requested, please note that this could delay the determination response. However, a reasonable effort will be made to fulfill the request within 10 calendar days of receipt.

communications.subject: City of Whittier - Public Records Extension Request
communications.communication:
Good evening Mr. Buhl,

In response to your California Public Records Act (CPRA) request dated March 21, 2024, regarding "any spreadsheet or list maintained by the WPD showing all invoices and purchase orders submitted by or paid to vendors. If such a spreadsheet can be produced from the Department's accounting software showing amount of payment, date of payment, payee, and description of reason for payment, then I am requesting that spreadsheet. Please cover a period going back to 2012," the City Clerk Department has compiled the following response:

California Government Code Section 7922.535 requires the City to provide a response to your request within 10 days of receipt indicating what, if any, of the documents sought will be disclosed. Government Code Section 7922.535 also permits the City to extend the period in which it responds to your request by an additional 14 days, if necessary. The City is requesting an extension because the City needs to compile and filter the data generated from a voluminous report through our financial software. As an example, the reports for FY 2022-23 and 2023-24 produced an excess of 1400 pages that need to be converted to excel and then filtered by department.  Once the records have been gathered, there will also be an examination to determine if any of the records are exempt from disclosure. A determination regarding your request will be sent to you no later than April 12, 2024, which is 14 days from the tenth day following the City's receipt of your request.

In the event the documents are collected and examined, and a determination on their disclosure is made prior to that time, we will provide you with that determination sooner. If you have any questions, please contact the City Clerk Department at (562) 567-9850.


[cid:image002.jpg@01DA8464.D542ECE0]<http://www.cityofwhittier.org/> City Clerk Department

title: Federal Marshal Operation on Jan 5, 2022 at Playa Palms Apartments (Department of Justice, United States Marshals)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Federal Marshal Operation on Jan 5, 2022 at Playa Palms Apartments (Department of Justice, United States Marshals)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

On January 5th, 2022 twenty or more armed US Marshals were present at the Playa Palms Apartments from approximately 9:00 am to 9:00 pm.  Along with 3 mobile command centers and numerous state, local, and county law enforcement officers.  Please disclose all documents pertaining to this operation.  Playa Palms Apartments is located at 2200 W San Angelo St, Gilbert AZ, 85233.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Victor Montoya

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

A log of all emails to/from the CPS Board Chair, from February 01, 2024 to February 29, 2024.

1. Please search all CPS email accounts as well as personal accounts used for public business. The log should include but not be limited to: sender, recipient(s), date and time, subject line, and attachment.

Because this request is in the public interest for Illinois nonprofit The FOIA Bakery’s work to advocate for public education, please waive any fees in accordance with 5 ILCS § 140/6(c). Feel free to contact me with any questions, or if clarification is needed.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Miriam Bhimani

communications.subject: Non-Commercial FOIA Request :: N014947-030324
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 
April 2, 2024 Miriam Bhimani 159582-57380573@requests.muckrock.com RE: Chicago Public Schools FOIA Request N014947-030324 
Dear Ms. Bhimani: This letter is in reply to your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request seeking the following information: A log of all emails to/from the CPS Board Chair, from February 01, 2024 to February 29, 2024. 

1. Please search all CPS email accounts as well as personal accounts used for public business. The log should include but not be limited to: sender, recipient(s), date and time, subject line, and attachment. RESPONSE : Documents responsive to your request are available to download via the CPS FOIA Center at www.cps.edu/FOIARequests . Please log in with your username and password to access the records. Under the rules of FOIA, private information and unique identifiers contained within public records are exempt from public disclosure; those portions have been redacted including personal email addresses and other highly personal information. Pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/7 (1)(b), “Private information, unless disclosure is required by another provision of this Act, a State or federal law or a court order,” and pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/7(1)(c), “Personal information contained within public records, the disclosure of which would constitute a clearly unwarranted invasion of personal privacy, unless the disclosure is consented to in writing by the individual subjects of the information. “Unwarranted invasion of personal privacy” means the disclosure of information that is highly personal or objectionable to a reasonable person and in which the subject’s right to privacy outweighs the legitimate public interest in obtaining the information. The disclosure of information that bears on the public duties of public employees and officials shall not be considered an invasion of personal privacy. Personally identifiable student record information has been redacted in accordance with the Illinois School Student Records Act 105 ILCS 10/1 et seq. and the corresponding Section 7.5(r) FOIA exemption (5 ILCS 140/7.5(r)). Redactions have been made pursuant to section 7(1)(f) which exempts from release “[p]reliminary drafts, notes, recommendations, memoranda and other records in which opinions are expressed, or policies or actions are formulated, except that a specific record or relevant portion of a record shall not be exempt when the record is publicly cited and identified by the head of the public body. The exemption provided in this paragraph (f) extends to all those records of officers and agencies of the General Assembly that pertain to the preparation of legislative authority.” 5 ILCS 140/7 (1)(f). Furthermore, this exemption is “intended to protect the communications process and encourage frank and open discussion among agency employees before a decision is made." State Journal-Register v. Univ. of Ill. Springfield, 994 N.E.2d 705, 713 (2013). Redactions have been made pursuant to section 7(1)(m) of the FOIA which exempts from release “[c]ommunications between a public body and an attorney [] representing the public body that would not be subject to discovery in litigation, and materials prepared or compiled by or for a public body in anticipation of a criminal, civil, or administrative proceeding upon the request of an attorney advising the public body.” 5 ILCS 140/7 (1)(m). Redactions have been made pursuant to section 7(1)(p) of the FOIA which exempts from release “[r]ecords relating to collective negotiating matters between public bodies and their employees or representatives, except that any final contract or agreement shall be subject to inspection and copying.” 5 ILCS 140/7(1)(p). To the extent you consider this a denial, pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/9.5(a) you may file a Request for Review with the Public Access Counselor (PAC) at: Public Access Counselor; Office of the Attorney General; 500 South 2nd Street; Springfield, IL 62706.  You also have the right to seek judicial review of your denial by filing a lawsuit in the State circuit court; 5 ILCS 140/11. If you have any questions, please contact our office at (773) 553-3500. Thank you for your request. Sincerely, Annie Righi Freedom of Information Act Officer Chicago Public Schools

Chicago Public Schools (CPS) responds to all public records requests in accordance with the Illinois Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq. 
Due to the volume and complexity of requests received in the normal course of business, CPS is extending the time for its initial response to your request by an additional 5 business days (to 10 business days total beginning on the first business day following receipt of the request) pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/3(e)(v) which allows for the examination and evaluation of the requested records by personnel to determine if they are exempt from disclosure under Section 7 of Illinois FOIA or should be revealed only with appropriate deletions. 
Upon the completion of a response, CPS will provide the first 50 pages to you at no charge.  If a response is more than 50 pages, a fee of 15¢ per page will be charged for each additional page. Copies of video recordings have a fee of $48. All applicable fees must be paid prior to the copying. CPS will inform you of any fees due if your paper response exceeds 50 pages. You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you’ll receive an email when your request has been completed. Thank you for using the CPS FOIA Center.

communications.subject: Non-Commercial FOIA Request :: N014931-022924
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 
April 2, 2024 Miriam Bhimani 159554-50654449@requests.muckrock.com 
RE: Chicago Public Schools FOIA Request N014931-022924 
Dear Ms. Bhimani: This letter is in reply to your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request seeking the following information: Records sufficient to show the following: 

1. Contents of emails and attachments highlighted on attached email log released via FOIA N014773-020124. RESPONSE : Documents responsive to your request are available to download via the CPS FOIA Center at www.cps.edu/FOIARequests . Please log in with your username and password to access the records. Under the rules of FOIA, private information and unique identifiers contained within public records are exempt from public disclosure; those portions have been redacted including race/ethnicity, cell phone numbers, personal email addresses, and other highly personal information. Pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/7 (1)(b), “Private information, unless disclosure is required by another provision of this Act, a State or federal law or a court order,” and pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/7(1)(c), “Personal information contained within public records, the disclosure of which would constitute a clearly unwarranted invasion of personal privacy, unless the disclosure is consented to in writing by the individual subjects of the information. “Unwarranted invasion of personal privacy” means the disclosure of information that is highly personal or objectionable to a reasonable person and in which the subject’s right to privacy outweighs the legitimate public interest in obtaining the information. The disclosure of information that bears on the public duties of public employees and officials shall not be considered an invasion of personal privacy. Further, redactions were applied to mask communications between a parent and their child’s school district pursuant to section 7(1)(c). Parents have a personal privacy interest under 5 ILCS 140/7(1)(c) in their identifying information when they contact their child’s school to express opinions. (See Ill. Att' y Gen. PAC Req. Rev. Ltr. 38873, issued June 30, 2016, at 4-5 and Ill. Att' y Gen. PAC Req. Rev. Ltr. 56488). Personally identifiable student record information has been redacted in accordance with the Illinois School Student Records Act 105 ILCS 10/1 et seq. and the corresponding Section 7.5(r) FOIA exemption (5 ILCS 140/7.5(r)). Redactions have been made pursuant to section 7(1)(f) which exempts from release “[p]reliminary drafts, notes, recommendations, memoranda and other records in which opinions are expressed, or policies or actions are formulated, except that a specific record or relevant portion of a record shall not be exempt when the record is publicly cited and identified by the head of the public body. The exemption provided in this paragraph (f) extends to all those records of officers and agencies of the General Assembly that pertain to the preparation of legislative authority.” 5 ILCS 140/7 (1)(f). Furthermore, this exemption is “intended to protect the communications process and encourage frank and open discussion among agency employees before a decision is made." State Journal-Register v. Univ. of Ill. Springfield, 994 N.E.2d 705, 713 (2013). Course materials or research materials used by faculty members have been redacted pursuant to section (j)(iv) of the FOIA. 5 ILCS 140/7(1)(j)(iv). Redactions have been applied pursuant to Section 7.5(h) of the FOIA, which exempts from disclosure “information the disclosure of which is exempted under the State Officials and Employees Ethics Act, and records of any lawfully created State or local inspector general’s office that would be exempt if created or obtained by an Executive Inspector General’s office.” 5 ILCS 140/7.5(h). Redactions have been made pursuant to section 7(1)(m) of the FOIA which exempts from release “[c]ommunications between a public body and an attorney [] representing the public body that would not be subject to discovery in litigation, and materials prepared or compiled by or for a public body in anticipation of a criminal, civil, or administrative proceeding upon the request of an attorney advising the public body.” 5 ILCS 140/7 (1)(m). Redactions have been made pursuant to section 7(1)(p) of the FOIA which exempts from release “[r]ecords relating to collective negotiating matters between public bodies and their employees or representatives, except that any final contract or agreement shall be subject to inspection and copying.” 5 ILCS 140/7(1)(p). Finally, please note that records that do not pertain to the transaction of public business have been withheld from release. To the extent you consider this a denial, pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/9.5(a) you may file a Request for Review with the Public Access Counselor (PAC) at: Public Access Counselor; Office of the Attorney General; 500 South 2nd Street; Springfield, IL 62706.  You also have the right to seek judicial review of your denial by filing a lawsuit in the State circuit court; 5 ILCS 140/11. If you have any questions, please contact our office at (773) 553-3500. Thank you for your request. Sincerely, Annie Righi Freedom of Information Act Officer Chicago Public Schools

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Cambridge Public Records Request Log - 2023
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, this is a request for records related to this agency’s receipt of and response to public records requests. 

For the period from January 1, 2023 through December 31, 2023, please provide all logs and available related details of public records requests received by this office. Responsive materials include those that describe the following details for each public records request received by this office: 
• The name of the requester and the affiliated organization
• The date on which the request was received by this office
• The city department for which the request was intended
• A description of the requested records
• The tracking number assigned by this office to the request
• The date on which the request was closed by this office
• The final disposition of the request, including, if possible, whether the request was fully fulfilled, partially fulfilled, rejected in its entirety, resulted in no responsive documents, or remains open
• Details on exemptions applied to responsive and withheld records
• The number of released pages

Please provide the responsive materials in the form of a spreadsheet (either in CSV or XLS file formats), if possible. 

This request is being made as part of an academic and journalistic project and is not being made for any commercial reason. In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request be fulfilled electronically, via e-mail attachment, the upload link in the footer of this message, or Dropbox, if possible.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Please contact me if your office has any questions about this request. 

Sincerely,

Beryl Lipton

communications.subject: Public Records Request :: P240094-011724
communications.communication:
Dear Beryl Lipton: 
Your public records request has been received by the City of Cambridge, and is being processed in accordance with Public Records Law. Your request was received in this office on 1/12/2024 and has been given the reference number P240094-011724 for tracking purposes. Requests received after hours, on weekends, or on a City of Cambridge Holiday are considered received on the next business day under the Public Records law, regardless of when they are actually received or entered into our system. Please be advised that the Massachusetts Public Records Law does not require a governmental body to create new records, conduct legal research, or answer questions, in order to provide a response to a request. 
The City of Cambridge Business Hours are as follows: M: 8:30 AM to 8:00 PM, T-W-Th: 8:30 AM to 8:00 PM, F: 8:30 AM to 12:00 PM. 
Sincerely, 
Seah Levy

communications.subject: OSTP FOIA 24-080 and 81
communications.communication:
Dear Maddie,

Are you asking for any research documents produced by a contractor? If so, then there are only 2 contractors who would have produced anything along those lines: ICF and STPI. STPI-related documents are publicly available here:https://www.ida.org/research-and-publications/publications#pageSize=12&pageIndex=0&sortby=publicationdate&sortdir=Desc&keyword=Office%20of%20Science%20and%20Technology%20Policy&filter=

With regards to ICF, we do not have a master list of all the contractors. However, you can find the list of contributors on their website here: https://www.globalchange.gov/
Additionally, NASA, not OSTP maintains ICF contracts.

Let  us know if you have any other question.

Thank you!

Regards,

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: ICF contracts
communications.communication:
Whoops, yes, I was asking for research documents produced by ICF.  I see that an ICF employee is listed as the 'coordinator' for the most recent National Climate Assessment, but I was wondering whether ICF consultants produced any specific documents that informed the assessment (or other OSTP projects).

Thanks for clarifying that NASA maintains the contracts--I will follow up with them.

Best,
Maddie

On March 11, 2024:
Subject: OSTP FOIA 24-080 and 81
Dear Maddie,

Are you asking for any research documents produced by a contractor? If so, then there are only 2 contractors who would have produced anything along those lines: ICF and STPI. STPI-related documents are publicly available here:https://www.ida.org/research-and-publications/publications#pageSize=12&pageIndex=0&sortby=publicationdate&sortdir=Desc&keyword=Office%20of%20Science%20and%20Technology%20Policy&filter=

With regards to ICF, we do not have a master list of all the contractors. However, you can find the list of contributors on their website here: https://www.globalchange.gov/
Additionally, NASA, not OSTP maintains ICF contracts.

Let us know if you have any other question.

Thank you!

Regards,

OSTP FOIA Team

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: Parent Restriction Letters, FY23, N1
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

Records sufficient to show copies of Parent Restriction letters issued from July 1, 2022 - June 30, 2023 for the following schools/instances:

1. Any district-wide issued letters;
2. Any letters issued by schools in Network One:
ALBANY PARK
BATEMAN
BEARD
BEAUBIEN
BELDING
BRIDGE
CANTY
CATALPA
CHICAGO ACADEMY
CLEVELAND
DEVER
DIRKSEN
EBINGER
EDGEBROOK
EDISON
EDISON PARK
FARNSWORTH
GARVY
GRAY
HENRY
HIBBARD
HITCH
MURPHY
NORWOOD PARK
ONAHAN
ORIOLE PARK
PETERSON
PORTAGE PARK
PRUSSING
REINBERG
SAUGANASH
SCAMMON
SMYSER
SOLOMON
STOCK
VOLTA
WILDWOOD


These may also be listed as "Violation of Visitor Protocol" letters. Please note that I am not seeking any personally identifiable information or otherwise exempt information. As required by the statute, please ensure that the requested documents are redacted rather than exempting the entirety of the document. Additionally, for any and all exemptions used to redact exempt information, please provide clear and convincing evidence for each exemption used by your agency.

Because this request is in the public interest for Illinois nonprofit The FOIA Bakery’s work to advocate for public education, please waive any fees in accordance with 5 ILCS § 140/6(c). Feel free to contact me with any questions, or if clarification is needed.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Miriam Bhimani

Chicago Public Schools (CPS) responds to all public records requests in accordance with the Illinois Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq. 
Due to the volume and complexity of requests received in the normal course of business, CPS is extending the time for its initial response to your request by an additional 5 business days (to 10 business days total beginning on the first business day following receipt of the request) pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/3(e)(v) which allows for the examination and evaluation of the requested records by personnel to determine if they are exempt from disclosure under Section 7 of Illinois FOIA or should be revealed only with appropriate deletions. 
Upon the completion of a response, CPS will provide the first 50 pages to you at no charge.  If a response is more than 50 pages, a fee of 15¢ per page will be charged for each additional page. Copies of video recordings have a fee of $48. All applicable fees must be paid prior to the copying. CPS will inform you of any fees due if your paper response exceeds 50 pages. You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you’ll receive an email when your request has been completed. Thank you for using the CPS FOIA Center. 

Track the issue status and respond at: https://cps.mycusthelp.com/WEBAPP//_rs/RequestEdit.aspx?rid=14778

RESPONSE: The CPS FOIA Office has reviewed your request and has determined the following: In response to number 1 of your request, the FOIA Office has conducted a due diligence search for records responsive to your request and has determined that no records responsive to your request were located. 
In response to number 2 of your request, the letters that the FOIA Office was able to locate are available to download via the CPS FOIA Center at www.cps.edu/FOIARequests . Please log in with your username and password to access the records. 
Please be advised that certain student and parent/guardian information was redacted pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/7.5 (r) which exempts from inspection or copying information prohibited from being disclosed by the Illinois School Student Records Act (ISSRA). ISSRA generally prohibits the disclosure of “school student records” and defines a “school student record” as “any writing or other recorded information concerning a student and by which a student may be individually identified, maintained by a school or at is direction or by an employee of a school, regardless of how or where the information is stored.” (105 ILCS 10/2(d). 5 ILCS 140/7(1)(j)(iii) exempts from release information concerning a school or university’s adjudication of student disciplinary cases, but only to the extent that disclosure would unavoidably reveal the identity of the student. 
Section 7(1)(c) exempts personal information contained within public records, the disclosure of which would constitute a clearly unwarranted invasion of personal privacy, unless the disclosure is consented to in writing by the individual subject of the information. “Unwarranted invasion of personal privacy” means the disclosure of information that is highly personal or objectionable to a reasonable person and in which the subject’s right to privacy outweighs any legitimate public interest in obtaining the information. 
You have a right to have the denial of your request reviewed by the Public Access Counselor (PAC) at the Office of the Illinois Attorney General. 5 ILCS 140/9.5(a). You can file your Request for Review with the PAC by writing to: Leah Bartelt; Public Access Counselor Office of the Attorney General 500 South 2nd Street Springfield, Illinois 62706 E-mail: public.access@ilag.gov 877-299-3642 You also have the right to seek judicial review of your denial by filing a lawsuit in the State circuit court. 5 ILCS 140/11. If you choose to file a Request for Review with the PAC, you must do so within 60 calendar days of the date of this denial letter. 5 ILCS 140/9.5(a). Please note that you must include a copy of your original FOIA request and this denial letter when filing a Request for Review with the PAC. Sincerely, Patricia Majchrowicz Freedom of Information Act Officer Chicago Public Schools

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

Sincerely,

e

title: K9 usage in Fitchburg Public Schools (Fitchburg Police Department)

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: K9 usage in Fitchburg Public Schools (Fitchburg Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

For ANY AND ALL canine use within the Fitchburg Public Schools between August 1, 2018 to the date of receipt of this FOIA request, please provide:

    1) the DATES, TIMES, AND DURATION of the canine use; and
    2) LOCATION of the canine use, as specific as possible (for example, if a canine search was limited to a bathroom then the school and room number; or if a canine search was performed on all lockers but did not extend into any classroom, then that should be noted); and
    3) the REASON(S) for the use; and
    4) the LEGAL JUSTIFICATION for the reason(s) for the use, citing statute and/or case law if possible; and
    5) the NAME OF THE POLICE DEPARTMENT(S) involved in the canine use, including but not limited to any police department present during the canine use even if that police department was not the owner or handler of the canine(s); and
    6) if the canine(s) is owned by a police department, the NAME(S) AND BADGE/ID NUMBER(S) of the canine(s) involved; and 
    7) if the canine(s) is NOT owned by a police department, the name(s) of the canine(s) involved, and the name, address, phone number, and email of the OWNER of the canine(s); and 
    8) if the canine(s) is NOT owned by a police department, the name(s) of the HANDLER(S) of the canine(s); and 
    9) if the canine(s) is NOT owned by a police department, any and all contracts, memorandum of understanding, memorandum of agreement, and any other official contract concerning the canine(s) and police department requesting the canine(s) use; and
    10) THE NAME(S) AND BADGE NUMBER(S) of the police department employee(s) involved; and the name(s) of the Fitchburg Public School ADMINISTRATOR(S) AND OTHER EMPLOYEES in charge of the canine use, including but not limited to any school employee who made the request, directly monitored the canine usage, or who otherwise acted as a school representative concerning the canine use; and
    11) any and all RESULTS of the canine use, including but not limited to non-productive searches; and
    12) if the canine use was requested or required by the Fitchburg Public Schools, the name of the Fitchburg Public School employee REQUESTOR(S); and
    13) if the canine use requested or required by the Fitchburg Police Department, the name of the Fitchburg Police Department employee REQUESTOR(S).

The term "canine" is intended to mean a police-owned or police-commissioned dog that is utilized for searches or other police functions within schools. Police functions also includes but is not limited to:
- searches
- demonstrations
- teaching
- training
- any other ancillary police function
as long as the canine use was performed in the Fitchburg Public School, on Fitchburg Public School owned property, and/or requested by the Fitchburg Public Schools.

The interest of this FOIA request is for the records produced or maintained by each department (for example, the Fitchburg Public School district, or the Fitchburg Police Department, and not simply one school within the system or one police building). Therefore this information must be from each department's records, and not coordinated with any other department, entity, agency, or group, unless that outside department's normally stores or maintains records for that department. For example, the school can provide a police report which the school has on file prior to this public records request, but should not request a police report from a police department solely in order to fulfill this public records request.

Fees for public records requests are defined in part in Massachusetts law 950 CMR 32.07 (2)(m) for municipal records and 950 CMR 32 (2) in general.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, processed by a representative of the news media/press and is made in the process of news gathering and not for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Neal Delfeld

communications.subject: Re: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: K9 usage in Fitchburg Public Schools (Fitchburg Police Department)
communications.communication:
Good afternoon,

As the designated Records Access Officer for the Fitchburg Police Department I have been tasked with responding your recent request for public records.

Today I received an email  in regards to a Public Records Request that was originally dated February 23, 2020  It appears that the original request was sent to the email address infor@fitchburgpolice.com<mailto:infor@fitchburgpolice.com>.

The above email address is not an active email address. After reviewing the specifics in this records request, this is the same data that was requested with the same language in February 10th of 2020. This request was answered by Captain Giannini on February 17, 2020

Captain Giannini responded with the data including several attachments. Included in this email are copies of the data submitted in the response along with copies of the emails outlining the communication.

The email chain below articulates the response.

Should you require any additional data or documents please reach out.

Please be advised that pursuant to 950 CMR 32.00 and G.L. Chapter 66, Section 10A(a) you have the right to appeal this decision to the Supervisor of Records, at the address listed below, within 90 days from your original request.  The appeal must include your original request along with this response.  Pursuant to G.L. Chapter 66, Section 10A(c) you also have the right to seek judicial review by commencing a civil action in the Superior Court.
Supervisor of Records

Office of the Secretary of the Commonwealth
McCormack Building, Room 1719
One Ashburton Place
Boston, MA 02108

I kindly request that you send me a return email acknowledging this response to your public records request.

Respectfully



[https://www.fitchburgma.gov/ImageRepository/Document?documentId=9639]  Captain Matthew LeMay
Technical Services Commander
Police Department
City of Fitchburg, Massachusetts
